question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [ANS processor vulnerability] Why is AnsProcessor explicitly disabled in localnet? Does enabling it pose a security risk that could be exploited if the bail! check is bypassed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [GasFeeProcessor exposure] Could bypassing the GasFeeProcessor restriction enable an attacker to manipulate gas fee tracking or exploit gas accounting vulnerabilities in the localnet? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [MonitoringProcessor risk] Does the disabled MonitoringProcessor have access to sensitive system metrics? Could enabling it leak information useful for attacking the localnet infrastructure? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Caller validation] Do the callers of get_processor_config (ProcessorManager::new and start_processor) properly validate the returned configuration before using it? Could a malicious configuration cause security issues downstream? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Configuration injection] When ProcessorManager::new constructs IndexerProcessorConfig using the returned processor_config, are all fields properly sanitized? Could an attacker inject malicious values through the configuration? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Database credential exposure] Does get_processor_config have access to database credentials that could be leaked through the configuration objects? Could an attacker extract postgres connection strings? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Transaction stream config] When callers combine processor_config with TransactionStreamConfig, could mismatched security settings between the two enable unauthorized transaction stream access? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Concurrent access] Is get_processor_config thread-safe? Could concurrent calls from multiple ProcessorManager instances cause race conditions when accessing Default::default() implementations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [State pollution] If Default::default() implementations maintain shared state, could concurrent processor initialization cause state pollution that affects processor behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Configuration caching] Is there any caching of processor configurations? Could a time-of-check-time-of-use (TOCTOU) race condition allow an attacker to substitute a malicious configuration? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Memory exhaustion] Could repeatedly calling get_processor_config cause memory exhaustion if the configuration objects allocate significant heap memory? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Stack overflow] Is there any recursive configuration construction that could cause stack overflow if processor configurations become deeply nested? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Clone safety] Are the ProcessorConfig variants properly Clone/Copy safe? Could cloning configurations create dangling pointers or use-after-free vulnerabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Unsafe code] Are there any unsafe blocks in the ProcessorConfig or related types that could cause undefined behavior when configurations are constructed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Lifetime violations] Could the returned ProcessorConfig contain references with improper lifetimes that lead to use-after-free when processors are spawned asynchronously? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Interior mutability] Do any of the configuration structs use interior mutability (Cell, RefCell, Mutex)? Could this enable data races when processors access the configuration concurrently? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [SQL injection] Do the processor configurations properly escape or parameterize database queries? Could default configurations enable SQL injection attacks against the Postgres database? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Connection string validation] Are postgres connection strings in calling code properly validated after get_processor_config returns? Could an attacker inject malicious connection parameters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Database pool exhaustion] Could the db_pool_size settings (hardcoded to 8 in callers) combined with processor configurations cause connection pool exhaustion when all processors start simultaneously? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Index poisoning] Could an attacker exploit processor configurations to poison the indexer database with incorrect data, causing state inconsistencies? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Starting version manipulation] When callers set starting_version to 0, could this cause the processor to re-index from genesis and overwrite legitimate indexed data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Transaction filtering bypass] Do the processor configurations properly respect transaction_filter settings? Could default configs allow processing of transactions that should be filtered? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Migration timing] When processors are started and RUN_MIGRATIONS_ONCE is used, could the configuration returned by get_processor_config cause migration conflicts if schema expectations don't match? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Version compatibility] Are the processor configurations forward/backward compatible? Could upgrading the processor crate break existing localnet deployments that rely on specific default configurations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Schema mismatch] If different processors expect different database schemas, could get_processor_config's default configurations cause schema conflicts when multiple processors share the same database? (Medium)
